text: [Music]
Well, there are two things I'd like to
say about that actually. One of them is
the question of social science. What is
the uh what does political philosophy
have to do with um the the prestige of
science, especially as it's played
itself out within the social sciences.
Today the most successful and the most
um prestigious social science is
economics because it's seen as the most
rigorous. It's seeing it it's thought
especially by many of its practitioners
to have arrived at a scientific
understanding of human behavior at least
where where markets and market behavior
are concerned. And in many ways,
scientistic understandings of economics,
detached from traditional normative
questions, traditional questions of
value, uh has a kind of momentum of its
own. As if economics uh uh were were a
science or a discipline that had
graduated from risen above connection
with mere speculation, which is what
philosophers are sometimes thought to
do. And there is something very heady
about that idea of economics as a as a
science even like like physics for
example. But I think it's a mistake and
I think it's shortsighted. I think the
most uh important and creative work in
the social sciences
uh in our lifetime and in the future
will be done by people who are
equipped with economic training and
concepts and categories but who can see
beyond it and who can
reconnect economics with what used to be
called moral and political economy. You
know, back in the days of Adam Smith,
David Hume, and John Stewart Mill, there
was one subject, moral and political
economy. The there was not political
philosophy on on the one hand and
economics, the science on the other. And
I think that some of the most exciting
development and new work will consist in
reconnecting the normative dimensions of
moral and political theory with economic
analysis. And we see this beginning in
debates about globalization for example
where the role of markets and normative
questions seem very hard to leave by the
wayside. So that's one area I think in
which the established social sciences
will um uh are in need of a kind of
leavenvening
uh and
deepening that can come if they
reconnect with questions not only of
policy but also of values and of norms
and of ideals.
[Music]
